title: Printrbot Z stabiliser with power switch and indicator

description.text:
As soon as I saw the original item I thought - hey I could hang some stuff off that! So I did - the stuff in this case being a power switch and 5mm LED indicator. I also plan to mount a small LCD on it as well in the future.
I had to modify the original significantly as the holes for the threaded bars weren't even close to mine. I modded the design to fit the standard Printrbot base measurements for the threaded rods - not sure what the original author was basing his off.
Download, modify to your liking for your particular switch and indicator, print, install!

title: AA Battery Adapters
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hate it when you're kickin' it old school and the batteries in the boombox dieâ€½
Keep the beats boomin' with a little 3D printer freshness!
Now, this won't change the battery output - this ain't no superhero thang - but it will keep the beats flowin' while you get to the local liquey-lack to grab the real deal.
Fresh for '88, er... 2010, boyeeeeeee!

• Print two adapters for each AA battery
  • Slide one onto each end of battery
  • Insert battery into boombox
  • Rinse, repeat (grail boxes like the Sharp GF-777Z and JVC RC-550 need ten D batteries!)
    • Ill! Mad props if you print or paint them gold, silver, or other funky fresh colors!

comments.text: Hello! The claw assembly is a fairly complex assembly with some small parts. I would suggest only attempting to replace the largest parts of this assembly as the smaller parts would likely be very tedious to print and would be fragile in their classical scale. This design has not been updated for a while I'm afraid. The benefit of the actual kit is that the real parts (from what I can tell) are either injection molded or metal, resulting in a more durable assembly.

description.text:
Nothing special about this switch. I just thought the original switches are sitting a bit loose and making them "noisy" when flipping the board. This one is a bit bigger and fits the board a bit better imo (not tight at all).
Also the gates are a bit loose, but I just scaled up the original gates found at "Printallot"'s design. I scaled them up in Cura with these ratio's:
X = Width of the gate when put on the board = 1,05
Y = Height of the gate when put on the board = 1,0 (unchanged)
Z = Thickness = 1,26
If you like the game, support "PrintAllot" and buy the game as a present maybe?

This is a stand for 2 felt-tip markers, that color your filament on the go. My results are best with white filament

  • Please 'LIKE' before collecting!
    Thomas

    • www.3daybreaker.blogspot.com

Update 19-01-2013: I have changed the measurements a bit and re-wrote it to be generally parametric. So you can easy finetune for your own brand of markers (I removed W.I.P. status for now) .STL file is for the item on the foto (In fact V2). The SCAD file is v3, not printed yet. Print with 15% infill, it need not be very strong. No support needed. Print one stand and 2 marker caps. It is designed for 1.75 mm filaments Extra material needed:

  • piece of sticky velcro.

  • 2 rubber bands
    • Maybe drill the filament hole a bit, for droops may have fallen into it. Drill a hole in the velcro for the filament. Retract the filament from the extruder (hot only) Feed the filament through the new stand and into the extruder again. Slide down the the stand and fix with some double sided velcro tape, matching the filament holes of it with the extruder. Put 2 markers in the support holes. Put caps on the markers add pressure to the caps by stretching the rubber bands over it to the hooks of the stand bottom. Start printing.

comments.text: How does this work?  When you print it melts the filament smaller than the origin size so I would think that you would just get striping of color in your print.  I don't believe it would change the color of the whole print but I have yet to try this out.

comments.text: You are correct, but it means that the color density will decrease. A dark blue marker will render the print light blue at that point. For more color pigment I use 2 markers. i am also developping a holder for 4 markers. The more ink, the better the color. But it will always be a mix of color with a lot of the original.

This is a small (~10cm tall) label holder for plants in flower pots.
The part is designed to be used with 20mm painters tape. The painters tape is easily removed when you change plants or at the end of the season so you can keep using the same holders. I make my labels out of a small piece of paints tape and use permanent marker to write the name of plant. For outdoor plants, I'll cover the label with a piece of clear tape. I will not grant Thingiverse an unconditional license to my source files so please go here for the Solidworks part files
https://github.com/KaiserSoft/3D-Printing
PLA @ 205C, 0,3mm layers, 25% infill, 2 perimeters, 2 top/bottom layers

Trammel Points allow you to draw out a really large, accurate circle.
Attach two trammel points to a long 10mm square bar of metal or wood, adjust their distance to the radius of the desired circle, and scribe your circle.

Print two of these, partially drill out the through 3mm hole and insert a sharpened bit of 3mm diameter steel, cut-off M3 screw, or whatever fits.  Don't drill through, as you want your pins to only go in so far.
Clean out the 10mm square holes, to make a tight fit on your rod of choice.
Slide the points onto the rod set their distance, and lock them down with the M3 setscrews.

description.text:
This part is designed to be a Hand Held Gimbal Mount for a Brushless camera Gimbal. This mount is used in conjunction with some Vibration Dampening Gromets to hold a Brushless Camera Gimbal, that is used for filming. The average small camera gimbal is used to mount into something like a Quadcopter, or airplane, but i decided to make a simple camera gimbal mount that you can hold in your hands, for whatever other uses you can find for your RC Camera Gimbal.
The reason that i made this is so I can have the ability to use the camera gimbal on my quadcopter for more than just capturing smooth aerial photography, but for also capturing smooth hand held photography.
The gimbal I use was 3D Printed and designed my Me, i am Running Turnigy HD 2212 Brushless Gimbal Motors, and an EVVGC Gimbal Control Board, with proper tuning i am able to get fantastic footage from such a simple device. The STL FIles For The Handle Mount Are 1/10th actual size. When printing scale up the model by 10 times to achieve actual size. UPDATE 1-23-17 --------------------------------- Hello everyone, Over the past many months and thousands of hours of design time I am nearly ready to release the final version of my consumer version of the Dimension 3 MultiMachine Delta 3D Printer. Check it out at http://www.Dimension3fab.com

I used an EVVGC board for the stabilisation control and some turnigy brushless gimbal motors. But this is completely universal! If you search on thingiverse for gimbal designs for a gopro you will find tons. This handle allows you to mount the base of the rotation motor to the handles, thus making it hand held, but it supports any gimbal design. RepRap 3D printer as a laser engraver.

Print the STL files and clip on your RepRap Pursa. A 1.6W 808nm Laser was used on the version.
Skeinforge can also generate laser milling g-code. If your laser have TTL control, you can replace the M101 & M103 code form M101 S255 & M101 S0 to control the laser on/ off. You need to connect the extruder heater power supply to the TTL control.

comments.text: Nothing changed with the firmware. Skeinforge setting as follow: profile type: Milling. Profile Selection: Laser. Chop: Tick Add Extra ....., Tick add Layer. Drill, untick Activate Drill. Export: Tick Activate Export, Tick ad Export Suffix.  Feed: Tick Activate Feed, feed rate: (15mm/s for deep colour, if the wood colour is light, decrease this value). Mill: Tick Activate Mill.    For the 2D laser milling, Skeinforge used for the G-code generate. For the 3D laser engraving, Artcam used for the G-code generate.

title: Modular Beast (Cyborg Beast derivative with support for modules)

description.text:
This is our version of Frankie Flood's modified Cyborg Beast designed for the e-NABLE community by Alex Hamm and Sam Sellner during our one month summer research residency at UW Milwaukee.
With this model we created a means of easily connecting and removing attachments for serving a wider variety of needs. Included with this model are two attachments, a traditional Cyborg Beast palm (Palm.stl) and an attachment for biking (Claw.stl). Please download the fingers and flanges from Frankie Flood's Cyborg Beast (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:308124).
Enjoy!
For more information on where to connect with people who can help someone in need with sizing, printing and/or assembly a mechanical hand please join the e-NABLE Google+ Community entitled, e-NABLE:
https://plus.google.com/communities/102497715636887179986
For more information and stories:
http://enablingthefuture.org
https://www.facebook.com/enableorganization

Gauntlet.stl, Mid-Gauntlet.stl, Claw.stl, and Palm.stl should all be printed with supports. The other files should print fine without supports.
Please download the fingers and flanges from Frankie Flood's Cyborg Beast (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:308124).
Some filing may be required to get the Tensioner-Block.stl to fit into the Gauntlet.stl. These parts should fit fairly snugly together.

title: Double Filament Spool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For mounting up to 4 smal amounts of filament on one (Ultimaker) hinge.
I designed this, because the Ultimaker features in the feature dual extrusion.
If you have test materials from different suppliers like me, they alsways send yo a short sample of ~5m. The filament always ravels in my room like crazy, so I decited to invent a thing for this.
You can change the filament on the core to match the combinations you want.
With this thing you can mount four colours on your Ultimaker / Printer.

Print:
  • 1 Core
  • 2 Mids
  • 6 Arms
  • 6 Frames (optional)
    • Screw with ISO 7380 M3x12mm (Metric Stainless Button Head Socket Cap Screws - linsenkopf mit i6k) 3 arms on one Mid. The holes on the side of the Arms should face to the outside, the curve of the mid to the inside (like on the Picture)
    Do the same with the other parts.
    Stick the mids on the core, curved end first. Turn the two minispools in opposit direction to check the friction. Optional:

title: C9 LED Bulb Replacement (Walmart Holiday Time)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement bulb for the Walmart Holiday Time  LED C9 Light Set. (One of our bulbs broke and I used it as an excuse to practice modeling and printing a very thin (translucent) object.
It is modeled in openSCAD so you can change the size of the bulb and the shape if you edit the numbers.

This can be a challenging print. To get it truly translucent, you will need to print it with no more than one or two layers (ideally with a natural or lightly pigmented PLA). I set my perimeters to 1 and zero infil and used a 2mm rim on the bottom to make sure it adhered and it printed fine on my Prusa Mendel.   I have included my Slic3r config for PLA.
You will either need to print it slowly, or enable cooling pauses or use a cooling fan, otherwise the thin walls get too soft and melt downwards.

author: OgoSport

description.text:
I designed this to use as a second water dispenser for our rats. We have one that is a bottle and a tube, but I'm not sure it's always working. Having this in the cage gives me peace of mind. The base always has 1/4" of water in it, until the bottle is empty.
I designed this so they had enough room to drink, but not enough room to stand and pee in it. The rats seem to prefer this dispenser over the tube type, even though they do get some of their bedding in it.
I designed this to be hard to tip over. When I first put it in the cage, one rat jumped on it. It didn't tip over. As the Rats get bigger and the water gets more empty, the story could be different. I may have to enlarge the base.
I've had water in it for several days and see no signs of leakage. Update 8/24/14 The rats found a way to pee in their water, so I've posted a new base that only has a small hole exposed for drinking. The rats can easily lap up water from the hole, but so far they haven't had good enough aim to pee in it.

I printed the bottle with 4 shells, which pretty much makes it solid. (It's only .05" thick). The bottle needs to be water and air proof.
The base I printed with 2 shells, since it only needs to be water proof.
Print both parts in the orientation shown in the screenshot and no support is necessary.

I made a simple phone stand for my galaxy blaze that can display it either horizontal or vertical. I rounded the edges on the bottom so there is no worry about screen contact. Updated!
I cut out about 1.5mm off the bottom of the stand as well as cutting slices in the bottom and back stand. Next I might do the back if I don't rubber coat it. I left the old version there in case you wanted one you could also use as a baton,

I made these to learn just how fine a feature my printer can resolve at different settings. One pin has raised bars and pins, the other has voids. Print them out to see how small you can go with things.
There are a 10mm void and pin on the left plus a set of pins or voids that are 5, 4, 3, 2, and 1mm. There are another set of 5,4,3,2,1 voids on the bottom.
The center has a square and a bar at 3, 2, 1, 0.9, 0.8, 0.7, 0.6, 0.5, 0.4, 0.3, 0.2, and 0.1 mm with another set running down the right side. Interestingly my printer generally stops at 0.6mm but does slightly better with lines running on the X axis and with voids rather than bars. Labels were added but they may or may not print - depends on your resolution.

Now you can catch them all! Provided they all fit inside a 3inch diameter ball :) Available for purchase via http://etsy.me/1smvOMb

Print pieces in the right color. For the hinge pin, I suggest at least 4 perimeters, for springy-ness.
In addition to the printed parts, you will need:
  • super glue: https://www.amazon.com/Gorilla-Super-Glue-Clear-Pack/dp/B01M2AAHAB/
  • 2 magnets (1/4" X 1/16")
    I'd also suggest using gloves whenever you combine superglue and rare earth magnets.
    • Assembly:
    1) Insert hinge pin into the black ring pieces, such that the 3rd pin is angled up at 90 degrees.
    2) Glue one of your two magnets into the hole for the top half. Wait for this to dry.
    3) Insert the white button into the black button holder. It might be a tight squeeze, so pliers are helpful.
    3) Find the correct orientation for the other magnet to go into the black button holder. Glue it in the right orientation, and wait for this to dry.
    4) Attach the black ring to the top piece via the hinge pin. Attach the button with the magnet. Squeeze the black ring so it fits snugly against the button. Apply super glue around the black ring and bottom of the button. Hold the bottom of the ball against the super glue you just applied. Allow to dry. Done!

M6 thread diameter 0.229 inch or 5.82mm
M6 hexhead side-to-side 0.385 inch or 9.78mm
the threadhole is ok, but the hexheads are smaller.
-for the thumbwheels:
M6 hexnut has a side-to-side diameter of 0.389 inch or 9.89mm
-for the frame:
the two screws for closing the frame are resembling M4 screws
the hole is ok but the M4 hexnut only has a side-to-side diameter of 0.272 inch or 6.93mm

this is a test
this is a test

The previous Mendel X bracket was compact, but led the toothed belt along a tortuous path with tight radii and reverses of direction. I've had the X axis belt snap (which costs far too much!), after just 4 sets of Mendel parts, and others have told me the same. With this, the design is larger, but less prone to belt failure. We've printed about 8 Mendels with it now with no sign of belt wear.

The X-axis ground rods need to be shorter, at 463 mm long. Also the X axis spacers and two sets of bearings and associated fastners are no longer needed. The motor is attached by 4 shorter, M3 x 12, cap screws not on the original BOM. Finally, the belt needs to be attached inside out compared to before, and as such the motor direction needs to be reversed. More details are here:
http://reprap.org/wiki/Mendel_Alternate_X_Motor_Bracket

comments.text: Slic3r demands a 10% (or something like that) buffer around the print bed for whatever reason. I often get rejected at 480mm on a 500mm bed. It's lame but there. My daughter bugged me to make this. There were only length extendable looms available on thingiverse. This allows length and width extensions. Photo shows 4 looms fitted together. STL file contains the 2 differently staggered parts needed. If it's not quite what you were looking for then do your own:

Base is shamfered so that bottom layer creep does not need cleaning up. In truth I did no cleaning up at all, printed, handed to daughter.

This is a derivative of Achim's "Clock4". This simple clock consists of several printed parts now: a stand, an outer ring, the face, and the hands (hour and minute only at this time). The movement is an inexpensive, but wonderfully rugged clock movement (made in the USA!) that I bought at Hobby Lobby for $7 and some change. When I saw Achim's original design, I liked it, and decided to print it. I think it will be nice to design several faces for it, so that the clock could be used as a seasonal piece, or relevant to a specal time of year or event. I may be adding more faces and outer rings, so stay tuned!

Instructions are "easy-peasy": 1.) Go get a clock movement. A standard 3/8" clock movement will work, and will cost less than $8 at Hobby Lobby or Michael's. They come with hands, and are probably going to be gold colored - you can use them if you want to, but they don't blend with the "printed" style. I used the gold clock hands for reference, and then discarded them. There will also be a wall hanging bracket that comes with the movement. If you want to mount this on the wall, you will need to modify the stand to allow for that. 2.) Print! 3.) Assembly instructions: the stand has three primary functions: one, it allows the clock to stand (surprising!). Second, it has a mounting hole in it for the movement (mounts from the back of the stand). Third, it has a clip at the bottom that holds the outer ring. <strong>a.) Mount the movement.</strong> In the 70's televsion show, "Kung Fu", the Chinese Master would say things like, "There is an order to the Universe, Grasshopper." This is no different. You can follow the instructions on the back of the clock movement box, and change the instructions accordingly, but the "order of the Universe" for this clock goes like this: place the black rubber washer (if your movement came with it) onto the movement itself. Then insert the movement's hand shaft, from the back of the stand, into the mounting hole. Next, push the outer ring into the stand's holding clip (see the picture of the clock). <i>Almost done!</i> Now place the face onto the hand shaft. You may have to wiggle things around a bit to get it to fit inside the outer ring, but you will get there. Then place the gold washer onto the hand shaft so that it rests against the clock face (again, see picture), and tighten the gold washer onto the hand shaft. It only needs to be a little more than finger tight - a good pair of pliers will help make the final turn or two. b.)Add the hands. The shorter of the two hands is the hour hand, so put that on first. You will see that only fits securely onto one of the hand shaft "shafts". Press it down a bit to make sure there is plenty of clearance between it and the minute hand, which you will add next. Now press the minute hand onto the hand shaft. The minute hand shaft is the smaller diameter shaft above the hour hand shaft. You will need to push down a little harder to get it onto the minute hand shaft since tolerances are a bit tighter here. Also, if you look, the minute hand shaft is "squared" off on two sides (magnifying glass works wonders here), which is how they all come. It is done that way to make a distinction between the hour and minute hand. Anyway, get that bad boy onto the shaft, and adjust as necessary. You want it to be pointing straight out, not pointing down or up (looks silly that way). c.) Put the AA sized battery in, and set the time. Voila! You have a clock that you printed, and can modify to give as gifts, show off with (I like that one the best), or simply keep around the dojo to tell the time. Thanks, and happy printing!

comments.text: For those of you having difficulty starting growing: clean the pit carefully, wrap the clean pit with wet paper tower, put in a zipper bag and leave above the fridge (for the heat) for a few weeks. comments.text: Well, the jury's still out. We're hoping to use it for scans of sculptures at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, but it feels really beta. description.text:
flexible tool holder that locks in any position.  
This is a work in progress. This is Version 1. I printed 16 links. It uses bailing wire for center tension. I used 4 #10 machine screws to assemble the 2 halves of the body, and a 5mm socket cap bolt to assemble the lever. I tried carpenters string to begin with but there was too much stretch in the string. The bailing wire seems to work. I plan on trying picture frame braided wire next. Whatever you try, it just needs to be a material that has very little stretch to it.  
I have supplied the step file for the project so you can make your own adjustments/tool holders, etc.

Using a solid countertop or workbech works good for this.

This is a handy holder for small video or still cameras that allows you to set the camera down on any surface or tripod mount. There is an optional Gopro mount for if you want to catch something in slow motion simultaneously. It features trapped nut and bolt design and is easy to assemble. The indent at the bottom accomodates different sized lens caps. Just print your own and superglue it in.
I've included a remix of a 49mm lens cap holder, which might work for you.
Update: Added a version of the handle that is 1/4" taller for larger hands.

Print top and bottom with support. I print support at 10% infill - it pops out with just a bit of exacto knife work. Your results may vary. The top and bottom fit together pretty snugly, but you will probably want to use ca glue (superglue) to make sure it doesn't come apart and destroy your camera. You will need a standard 1/4-20 nut for the bottom tripod mount and a 1/4-20 bolt between 1/4" and 1/2" long where the main camera attaches. You may have to trim the bolt so your camera seats properly.
The knurled knob stays in place when you push in the 1/4" bolt from underneath. Make sure it fits properly and turns smoothly before you glue the top and bottom together.

title: Seat Wedge Receiver for GoPro or Swann Camera system

description.text: This is a bracket to hold a Swann POV camera on the back of my bike, attached to the wedge pack under my seat.  It is inserted through a loop on the back and held at the top by the velcro holding it to the seat.  There are holes all over the bracket to allow elastic bands to be strung through which adds some shock absorbing properties to the bracket.  Also it can be used just to mount to stuff since it has lots of holes.

Build on platform with the receiver facing out and the support tabs facing down.  Snap off tabs when finished.  Lightly file the inner surfaces of the receiver before use and it will make it easier to insert and remove the bracket.  Built on a TOM in PLA using Sailfish accelerated.  MK7 extruder, 2 extra shells and 10% fill.
I broke one just to see how strong it was before trusting it with my camera, it took considerable force.  Of course if you are concerned with the strength of your build, a safety leash would be an easy and reasonable option.

comments.text:
In the picture you see Vertical the Y Belt and horizontal the X Belt. Following related to the picture.
The Y Belt is fixed with the original holders. It goes over the Pulley in the middle to eliminate vibrations.
The X Belt is fixed on right hand side with original holder. On the left hand side, not visible in picture, it is fixed with this belt tensioner http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:130235 In the middle it goes with it's backside over a group of bearings to take vibrations off
The middle block is more less to tension the belts but taking belt vibrations from caddy.

title: Magnetic Effector and Carriages for 3DR Simple

description.text:
The project of converting my 3DR Simple to use magnetic ball joints caused me a lot of grief. Despite the apparently successful video, I was never able to get the thing to print reliably when the print head was attached. Rods would always randomly pop out and cause havoc.   
Proceed at your own risk.

Magnetic effector plate and carriages for 3DR Simple that uses countersunk circular magnets and steel ball-bearings attached to the rods. Watch it move here. Effector has slots for nylon wire ties for wiring tidiness. Carriages have removable sections to make attaching and removing spectra line easier (change the carriage without cutting the spectra line!). Work in progress.

remixed_from.title: PG35L Micro Extruder V4 - For J-Head

title: PG35L Micro Extruder V5 - For J-Head

description.text:
Version 5 is designed for short and long  shaft PG35L-048 motors. This version has  2 integrated bearing to appose idler tension and minimize any shaft wobble.  Also, this body has a snap-in slot for a J-Head hot end which eliminates the aluminum slot plate.  This Micro Extruder has been tested on MendelMax and Prusa.  
Latest design change moves the support bearings closer to the PG35L motor for more surface contact with the Drive Gear.  Use me_body_v5_3mm.stl.  We also added a Buddaschnozzle version.  
Visit www.ultibots.com for Hobbed Drive Gears and Bearings. MendelMax Kits, Printed Parts, Filament, Electronics, and More are also available.  
Alibre PE source files included.

Hardware required:
M3x30 bolts and M3 jam nuts for the idler (x2)
M3x25 bolts and M3 jam nuts for the motor mount (x2)
624ZZ bearings for internal body (x2)
624ZZ bearings for idler (x1)
M4x20 bolts and M4 jam nuts for the idler bearing (x1)
M4 washers either side of idler bearing (x2)
M4-20 bolts and M4 jam nuts for the internal bearings (x2)
M4-10 bolts and M4 jam nuts to secure to x-carriage (x2)
M4 washers either side of internal bearings (x4) You will need to remove and drill out the support layers on the idler and body. Try our gear puller:
thingiverse.com/thing:31660 01/13/13 - uploaded v5.1 for 623ZZ bearings. Use M3 hardware for bearings.
01/14/13 - uploaded version without J-Head snap-in.
01/22/13 - uploaded 624ZZ idler.
01/22/13 - uploaded v5 body for 1.75mm filament. *corrected snap-in slot 02/11/13
03/31/13 - uploaded v5 body for 3mm with mounting holes centered on filament hole. Untested, may have interference issues with PG35L mount holes.

description.text: Sometimes at work something is out of your reach.  You’re a winner and won’t give up so you say “Fork it” or “Fork you” (preferably to the item out of reach, not a coworker).  The man’s not going to keep me down!  Anyways, here is a little keychain I whipped up for the guys at work. They were always digging around in the drawer looking for the fork truck key.  This is a stylish keychain that has functionality too!  One end has a hole for a split ring to put the key on. The other end has a hole for a 1/4 x 1/4 Inch Neodymium Rare Earth Cylinder N48 Magnet that I bought off of eBay from seller mfcom.  It allows the keychain to be stuck up on a cabinet or any other ferrous place you desire!  Now you can dork out in the shipping and receiving area too. Enjoy!
Printed this at 35% fill, honeycomb.  Used PLA.  Works great!

author: slipshine

description.text:
Ever needed a pad to put hot kitchenware on? This hot pad is 7.5" in diameter and has a cool design in the center.
Does it say true or false in the center?
Rotate to inspect
There are 2 versions.  One has the central symbol cut from the pad while the other has the symbol extruded from the pad.  It is up to you to decide which to download.
Use in the case of emergency.

Print the scratch head, take a 3/4" tube (or similar stick) and use an adhesive tape to place the head.
Use it when your back desperately needs to be scratched.
